Award.AwardTitle: AIS:Learning Motor Skills from Trajectory-based Reinforcement Learning

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research addresses the question of how complex future robotic systems, e.g., like humanoid assistive robots, can acquire, refine, and maintain a variety of motor skills that enable them to operate autonomously in normal human environments. Humans excel in their abilities to perform motor skills due to various aspects, including i) imitation learning, which allows them to transfer prior knowledge about a task from a teacher to a student, ii) trial-and-error learning, which provides them with means to refine skills, iii) reactive behaviors, which can deal with dynamic and stochastic environments, and iv) compliant control, which is a basic mechanism for robustness against disturbances and promotes safety to act amongst other humans. Understanding the basic mechanisms of these abilities will lead to technological advances towards truly autonomous robotic systems.
Our technical work includes research on modular representations of motor control in terms of movement primitives, research on trial-and-error improvement of motor primitives and sequences of motor primitives with trajectory-based reinforcement learning using novel techniques from probabilistic reinforcement learning and path-integral reinforcement learning, research on reactive behavior using direct coupling of motor primitives to perceptual variables, and compliant control with the help of operational space controllers that can be learned. Besides traditional benchmark simulation studies, our evaluations will include the learning of motor skills with a full-body humanoid robot, a system that significantly challenges the scalability of our methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed the question of how complex future robotic systems, e.g., like humanoid assistive robots, can acquire, refine, and maintain a variety of motor skills that enable them to operate autonomously in normal human environments. Humans excel in their abilities to perform motor skills due to various aspects, including i) imitation learning, which allows them to transfer prior knowledge about a task from a teacher to a student, ii) trial-and-error learning, which provides them with means to refine skills, iii) reactive behaviors, which can deal with dynamic and stochastic environments, and iv) compliant control, which is a basic mechanism for robustness against disturbances and promotes safety to act among other humans. Understanding the basic mechanisms of these abilities will lead to technological advancesvtowards truly autonomous robotic systems.

The project made major advances in various areas. It pushed the view of working with movement primitives, i.e., a small libarary of movement skills, and how to formulate and learn those skills with machine learning. It also added novel insights about creating skills that are inherently safe, i.e., that cannot easily harm other people. Another component was to understand human movement using the theory of mind, i.e., to understand what another person is doing by reflecting how this task can be done with once own body.

A fair amount of research was spent to deal with uncertain and changing enviroinments, i.e., how to be reactive to unforeseen situation, how to replan movements and recover from failures. This topic led to the idea to work with very sensory rich robots, i.e, robots with vision, tactile sensing, force sensing, etc., and to use machine learning to interpret such data for more advance moiton planning and control

Experimental evaulations were conduction with robots that perform complex manipulation tasks and that could walk over complex terrains.

From a technical point of view, we advanced knowledge of real-time learning and adaptive control in dynamic and stochastic environments, probabilistic approaches to learning control, and technical realization on one of the most advanced humanoid robots in the world.

As a broader Impact, we addressed that in not too far in the future, robots will become a natural part of the human society, with the aim of assisting broad populations in need, ranging in age, capability and context: in hospitals, schools, elder care facilities, inner city urban areas, and eventually homes. Targeted applications include assistance for the growing elderly population, for people with physical and cognitive disabilities, guidance of children and other at-risk populations on their commute, crowd and emergency response in densely populated areas, robotic rehabilitation and prosthetics, movement instructions for training, exercise, and entertainment activities, science education for children and minorities, search and rescue efforts, space exploration and maintenance in space, etc. These domains are typically understaffed due to the high cost of the number and/or training levels of personnel required for individualized assistance, or they pose unacceptable hazards or living environments to human operators. These research topics also falls directly into one of the fourteen Grand Challenge topics published by the National Academy of Engineering in 2008, i.e., the challenge of “Reverse Engineering the Brain”, with a subcomponent of “How close can machines come to human intelligence?”
